ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: 1. You heard someone say "that's so gay'' in a negative way.
2. You were told, ''you're not really gay.''
3. You were told you're not a ''real'' man/woman.
4. You were told not to ''act so gay.''
5. You were told you just haven't found the right person of the opposite sex.
6. You heard that people of your ethnicity aren't gay or bisexual.
7. You were told that being gay is just a phase.
8. Someone said, ''you are not like those gay people.''
9. Someone said, ''you know how gay people are.''
10. Someone expressed a stereotype (example: ''gay men are so good at fashion'').
11. You heard someone talk about ''the gay lifestyle.''
12. You heard about people trying to deny rights for same-sex couples (example: ''Proposition 8'' in California).
13. A heterosexual person seemed uncomfortable because they thought you were attracted to them.
14. You saw a group either in person or in the media show negative signs (example: A religious group with a sign that said ''God hates fags'').
15. Someone said gay, lesbian, and bisexual people are trying to get ''special rights'' that they don't deserve.
16. Someone said, ''I don't mind gay people, they just shouldn't be so public.''
17. Someone said a hateful slur about gay, lesbian, and bisexual people (example: ''fag'' or ''dyke'' said in a mean way).
18. A family member expressed disappointment about being gay, lesbian, or bisexual.
19. Someone said homosexuality is a sin or immoral.
20. A heterosexual person said you are being ''paranoid'' when you suspect someone treated you in a homophobic way.
21. A heterosexual person didn't believe that gay, lesbian, and bisexual people face discrimination.
22. You were told you were overreacting when you talked about a negative experience you had because of your sexual orientation.
23. A heterosexual denied that they have any heterosexism (example: ''As a person of color, I'm offended that you would imply I'm homophobic'').
24. Someone assumed you have HIV because of your sexual orientation.
25. Someone assumed you must be depressed because of your sexual orientation.
26. Someone implied that only heterosexuality is normal (example: ''Did you go to a gay bar or a normal bar?'').
